detail.content: Taste of the Yeats Summer School    | Glucksman Ireland House | New York University                Ticketed ">                              Skip to page Content.     NEW YORK UNIVERSITY     ARTS AND SCIENCE     COLLEGE OF ARTS AND SCIENCE     GRADUATE SCHOOL OF ARTS AND SCIENCE                                       Home       About Us       Undergraduate Studies       Graduate Studies       Academic Initiatives       Events       Membership       Community             Stay Connected           sign up       like us on Facebook       follow us on Twitter       watch us on Youtube       now on iTunes       listen to our radio hour                 Home > Events > Taste of the Yeats Summer School             Taste of the Yeats Summer School   Saturday, April 11th, 10:00 a.m. – 5:00 p.m.         at       Glucksman Ireland House NYU     Celebrate the 150th anniversary of the birth of William Butler Yeats with a full day of talks and readings. This annual day of all things Yeats, organized by the Yeats Society of NY in partnership with GIH NYU, is just a taste of a two-week program in Sligo, Ireland, that includes a tour of "Yeats Country." This year's Taste of the Yeats Summer School includes talks by Patricia Coughlan of University College Cork, John Harrington of Fordham University, Lucy McDiarmid of Montclair State University, Howard Keeley of Georgia Southern University, and poet Nuala Ni Dhomhnaill. Along with a full day of programs, there will be information on the 55th Yeats Summer School in County Sligo. Prof. Lucy McDiarmid will also be speaking at Glucksman Ireland House NYU on Thursday, April 9th at 7pm to launch her new book, Poets and the Peacock Dinner: The Literary History of a Meal . Fees Entire program, including refreshments and the afternoon social is $30; morning only $20; afternoon with social $25. To register, please fill out this form and send it, along with a check to WB Yeats Society of NY, National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park South, NYC 10003    with your name, address, phone number, email. Put the date on your   calendar; your name will be on a registration list at the door. Fees are   $5 more at door. Please check back to this webpage or www.yeatssociety.org for further information about registering for the event via the Yeats Society of New York. There is a $5 discount for members of Glucksman Ireland House NYU . Registration is available both in person at the door or get a $5 discount by registering in advance.  Program 9:30: Registration and refreshments - Irish tea and coffee (courtesy of Bewley’s), baked goods all day. 10:00 : Opening remarks–Andrew McGowan, president, WB Yeats Society of NY. 10:15 : “‘Each drop/distinct and perfect’: Mourning and Reparation in Paul Meehan’s Painting Rain” Patricia Coughlan , emerita professor at University College Cork currently Fulbright Scholar at Fordham, discusses how this 2009 collection is the work of a distinguished poet at the height of her powers (Meehan had a poem on the shortlist,along with Yeats’s “Easter 1916, to be voted Ireland’s best-loved poem written in the past 100 years). After briefly discussing Meehan’s contexts, influences and early work, the talk focusses on the role of loss, memory and creative recuperation in the collection. 11:00: Refreshment break. We’ll have books and other items for sale. 11:15: “‘Excess of Love’: Yeats and the Rebels of 1916” Lucy McDiarmid, Marie Frazee-Baldassare Professor of English at Montclair State, looks at the relation between romantic love and political idealism in the lives of the 1916 rebels, contrasting the way Yeats sees that relation in his poetry (“Hearts with one purpose alone”) and the way the executed men saw themselves. 12:30 : Luncheon on your own, with many Greenwich Village restaurants to choose from (we’ll give you a list). 2:00: “Yeats in America” Yeats visited the U.S. five times between 1903 and 1923. All the tours had fund-raising purposes: for the Irish theater, Thoor Ballylee, John Butler Yeats or the Irish Academy of Letters. John Harrington , dean of faculty of arts and science at Fordham, discusses how on these tours Yeats used his position as an international figure to promote Ireland’s arts and culture. 2:45: “Ignored: Yeats’s William Allingham” When considering Yeats’s formative Irish influences, critics regularly mention the so-called Bard of Ballyshannon. But they typically don’t dwell on him, despite Yeats’s admonition that Allingham should not be “ignored.” Howard Keeley , director of the Center for Irish Research and Teaching at Georgia Southern, explores the nexus between the two poets, beginning with the observation that both identified with Protestant merchant families from the coastal west of Ireland.. 3:30: A reading by Nuala Ni Dhomhnaill , a leading poet writing in Irish today. Her writings (she also writes children’s plays, screenplays and essays) focus on traditions and ancient folklore, combined with themes of femininity, sexuality and culture. 4:15-5 Social and a Summer School reunion. Wine and refreshments.  Presented by the WB Yeats Society of New York in partnership with Glucksman Ireland House NYU. For queries about the event, please contact the Yeats Society at info@yeatssociety.org .      All events are supported by members of Glucksman Ireland House. Become a member .                           Áras Glucksman na hÉireann                      Ollscoil Nua Eabhrac                  Glucksman Ireland House                  New York University                  One Washington Mews                  New York, NY 10003                  U.S.A.             Directions     Phone: 212.998.3950   Fax: 212.995.4373         Email:        ireland.house@nyu.edu         Sitemap | Contact Us | © New York University , Arts and Science

Taste of the Yeats Summer School    | Glucksman Ireland House | New York University                                              Skip to page Content.     NEW YORK UNIVERSITY     ARTS AND SCIENCE     COLLEGE OF ARTS AND SCIENCE     GRADUATE SCHOOL OF ARTS AND SCIENCE                                       Home       About Us       Undergraduate Studies       Graduate Studies       Academic Initiatives       Events       Membership       Community             Stay Connected           sign up       like us on Facebook       follow us on Twitter       watch us on Youtube       now on iTunes       listen to our radio hour                 Home > Events > Taste of the Yeats Summer School             Taste of the Yeats Summer School   Saturday, April 5th, 2014, 10:00 a.m. – 5:00 p.m.         at       Glucksman Ireland House NYU     Every summer, aficionados of the poet William Butler Yeats come from all over the world to enjoy two weeks of lectures, readings and theater in Sligo, Ireland, and to tour nearby ”Yeats Country.” Here is an opportunity to sample the Yeats International Summer School for a day in New York. Along with a full day of programs, there will be information on the 54th Yeats Summer School in County Sligo.      Speakers will include Geraldine Higgins, C.L. Dallat, and Anne-Marie Fyfe, as well as the Spiral Theatre's production of "Gonne/Yeats." Prof. Geraldine Higgins will also be speaking at Glucksman Ireland House NYU on Thursday, April 3rd: “News that stays New: The Future Life of W.B. Yeats” .       Download the full program here . All registration materials should be sent to the Yeats Society of NY, as detailed in the document. To submit:             Print, fill out, and send the form , along with a check, to WB Yeats Society of NY, National Arts Club, 15 Gramercy Park South, NYC 10003 with your name, address, phone number, e-mail. Put the date on your calendar; your name will be on a registration list at the door.    Glucksman Ireland House NYU members receive discounted registration rates. Fees are $5 more at door.                Entire program, including luncheon, refreshments and the afternoon social is $39 ($25 without the luncheon)         morning only $15         afternoon with social $20         luncheon only $20            Presented by the WB Yeats Society of New York in partnership with Glucksman Ireland House NYU. For queries about the event, please contact the Yeats Society at info@yeatssociety.org .      All events are supported by members of Glucksman Ireland House. Become a member .
